data.label: Start
data.name: seqStart
data.description: Starting point of the conversation

inputAnchors.label: Chat Model
inputAnchors.name: model
inputAnchors.description: Only compatible with models that are capable of function calling: ChatOpenAI, ChatMistral, ChatAnthropic, ChatGoogleGenerativeAI, ChatVertexAI, GroqChat

inputAnchors.label: Agent Memory
inputAnchors.name: agentMemory
inputAnchors.description: Save the state of the agent

inputAnchors.label: State
inputAnchors.name: state
inputAnchors.description: State is an object that is updated by nodes in the graph, passing from one node to another. By default, state contains "messages" that got updated with each message sent and received.

inputAnchors.label: Input Moderation
inputAnchors.description: Detect text that could generate harmful output and prevent it from being sent to the language model
inputAnchors.name: inputModeration

outputAnchors.name: seqStart
outputAnchors.label: Start
outputAnchors.description: Starting point of the conversation

data.label: State
data.name: seqState
data.description: A centralized state object, updated by nodes in the graph, passing from one node to another

tabs.label: Custom State (Table)
tabs.name: stateMemoryUI
tabs.description: Structure for state. By default, state contains "messages" that got updated with each message sent and received.

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
Specify the Key, Operation Type, and Default Value for the state object. The Operation Type can be either "Replace" or "Append".

**Replace**
- Replace the existing value with the new value.
- If the new value is null, the existing value will be retained.

**Append**
- Append the new value to the existing value.
- Default value can be empty or an array. Ex: ["a", "b"]
- Final value is an array.

tabs.label: Custom State (Code)
tabs.name: stateMemoryCode
tabs.description: JSON object representing the state

outputAnchors.name: seqState
outputAnchors.label: State
outputAnchors.description: A centralized state object, updated by nodes in the graph, passing from one node to another

data.label: Condition Agent
data.name: seqConditionAgent
data.description: Uses an agent to determine which route to take next

inputParams.label: System Prompt
inputParams.name: systemMessagePrompt
inputParams.default:
You are an expert customer support routing system.
Your job is to detect whether a customer support representative is routing a user to the technical support team, or just responding conversationally.

inputParams.label: Conversation History
inputParams.name: conversationHistorySelection

options.label: User Question
options.name: user_question
options.description: Use the user question from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: Last Conversation Message
options.name: last_message
options.description: Use the last conversation message from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: All Conversation Messages
options.name: all_messages
options.description: Use all conversation messages from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: Empty
options.name: empty
options.description: Do not use any messages from the conversation history. Ensure to use either System Prompt, Human Prompt, or Messages History.

inputParams.description: Select which messages from the conversation history to include in the prompt. The selected messages will be inserted between the System Prompt (if defined) and Human Prompt.

inputParams.label: Human Prompt
inputParams.name: humanMessagePrompt
inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message
inputParams.default:
The previous conversation is an interaction between a customer support representative and a user.
Extract whether the representative is routing the user to the technical support team, or just responding conversationally.

If representative want to route the user to the technical support team, respond only with the word "TECHNICAL".
Otherwise, respond only with the word "CONVERSATION".

Remember, only respond with one of the above words.

inputParams.label: Format Prompt Values
inputParams.name: promptValues
inputParams.description: Assign values to the prompt variables. You can also use $flow.state.<variable-name> to get the state value

inputParams.label: JSON Structured Output
inputParams.name: conditionAgentStructuredOutput
inputParams.description: Instruct the LLM to give output in a JSON structured schema

tabs.label: Condition (Table)
tabs.name: conditionUI
tabs.description: If a condition is met, the node connected to the respective output will be executed

tabs.label: Condition (Code)
tabs.name: conditionFunction
tabs.description: Function to evaluate the condition

hint.label: How to use

inputAnchors.label: Chat Model
inputAnchors.name: model
inputAnchors.description: Overwrite model to be used for this agent

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
You are an expert finding relevant information related to the user's question. 
Prioritized searching in the vector store first. If the context doesn’t fully address the question, provide a general but accurate response from the websearch.

data.label: End
data.name: seqEnd
data.description: End conversation

data.label: LLM Node
data.name: seqLLMNode
data.description: Run Chat Model and return the output

inputParams.label: Prepend Messages History
inputParams.name: messageHistory
inputParams.description: Prepend a list of messages between System Prompt and Human Prompt. This is useful when you want to provide few shot examples

inputParams.label: Conversation History
inputParams.name: conversationHistorySelection

options.label: User Question
options.name: user_question
options.description: Use the user question from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: Last Conversation Message
options.name: last_message
options.description: Use the last conversation message from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: All Conversation Messages
options.name: all_messages
options.description: Use all conversation messages from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: Empty
options.name: empty
options.description: Do not use any messages from the conversation history. Ensure to use either System Prompt, Human Prompt, or Messages History.

inputParams.description: Select which messages from the conversation history to include in the prompt. The selected messages will be inserted between the System Prompt (if defined) and [Messages History, Human Prompt].

inputParams.label: Human Prompt
inputParams.name: humanMessagePrompt
inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message

inputParams.label: Format Prompt Values
inputParams.name: promptValues
inputParams.description: Assign values to the prompt variables. You can also use $flow.state.<variable-name> to get the state value

inputParams.label: JSON Structured Output
inputParams.name: llmStructuredOutput
inputParams.description: Instruct the LLM to give output in a JSON structured schema

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                     |
    |-----------|---------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.content`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.label: Update State (Code)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Return the key value JSON object. For example: if you have the following State:
    ```json
    {
        "user": null
    }
    ```

    You can update the "user" value by returning the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": "john doe"
    }
    ```

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can return the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": $flow.output.content
    }
    ```

3. You can also get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values. Must return an object representing the state

inputParams.label: Require Approval
inputParams.name: interrupt
inputParams.description: Require approval before executing tools

inputParams.label: Approval Prompt
inputParams.name: approvalPrompt
inputParams.description: Prompt for approval. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled
inputParams.default: You are about to execute tool: {tools}. Ask if user want to proceed

inputParams.label: Approve Button Text
inputParams.name: approveButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for approve button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

inputParams.label: Reject Button Text
inputParams.name: rejectButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for reject button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the Tool Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure (array):
    ```json
    [
        {
            "tool": "tool's name",
            "toolInput": {},
            "toolOutput": "tool's output content",
            "sourceDocuments": [
                {
                    "pageContent": "This is the page content",
                    "metadata": "{foo: var}"
                }
            ]
        }
    ]
    ```

    For example:
    | Key          | Value                                     |
    |--------------|-------------------------------------------|
    | sources      | `$flow.output[0].toolOutput`       |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

inputParams.description: Require approval before executing tools

inputParams.label: Approval Prompt
inputParams.name: approvalPrompt
inputParams.description: Prompt for approval. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled
inputParams.default: You are about to execute tool: {tools}. Ask if user want to proceed

inputParams.label: Approve Button Text
inputParams.name: approveButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for approve button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

inputParams.label: Reject Button Text
inputParams.name: rejectButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for reject button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the Tool Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure (array):
    ```json
    [
        {
            "tool": "tool's name",
            "toolInput": {},
            "toolOutput": "tool's output content",
            "sourceDocuments": [
                {
                    "pageContent": "This is the page content",
                    "metadata": "{foo: var}"
                }
            ]
        }
    ]
    ```

    For example:
    | Key          | Value                                     |
    |--------------|-------------------------------------------|
    | sources      | `$flow.output[0].toolOutput`       |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After tool execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                     |
    |-----------|---------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.content`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.label: Update State (Code)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Return the key value JSON object. For example: if you have the following State:
    ```json
    {
        "user": null
    }
    ```

    You can update the "user" value by returning the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": "john doe"
    }
    ```

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can return the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": $flow.output.content
    }
    ```

3. You can also get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values. Must return an object representing the state

inputParams.name: humanMessagePrompt
inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message
inputParams.default:
The previous conversation is an interaction between a customer support representative and a user.
Extract whether the representative is routing the user to the technical support team, or just responding conversationally.

If representative want to route the user to the technical support team, respond only with the word "TECHNICAL".
Otherwise, respond only with the word "CONVERSATION".

Remember, only respond with one of the above words.

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
You are a grader assessing relevance of a retrieved document to a user question.

If the document contains keyword(s) or semantic meaning related to the question, grade it as relevant.

!! Do not answer the question yourself. Simply grade the relevance of the document to the question.

This carefully and objectively assess whether the document contains at least some information that is relevant to the question even if it is mildly related.

Return JSON with two keys, score, that is 'yes' or 'no' score to indicate whether the document contains at least some information that is relevant to the question. The second key is reasoning, where you need to explain the reasoning behind your decision.

Here is the retrieved document: 
{context}

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
You are a teacher grading a quiz. 

You will be given FACTS and a STUDENT ANSWER. 

Here is the grade criteria to follow:

(1) Ensure the STUDENT ANSWER is grounded in the FACTS. 

(2) Ensure the STUDENT ANSWER does not contain "hallucinated" information outside the scope of the FACTS.

Score:

A score of yes means that the student's answer meets all of the criteria. This is the highest (best) score. 

A score of no means that the student's answer does not meet all of the criteria. This is the lowest possible score you can give.

Explain your reasoning in a step-by-step manner to ensure your reasoning and conclusion are correct. 

Avoid simply stating the correct answer at the outset.
inputs.humanMessagePrompt:
FACTS: 

{context} 

 STUDENT ANSWER: 

{generation}. 

Return JSON with two two keys, grade is 'true' or 'false' score to indicate whether the STUDENT ANSWER is grounded in the FACTS. And a key, reasoning, that contains an explanation of the score.

data.label: Pinecone
data.name: pinecone
data.description: Upsert embedded data and perform similarity or mmr search using Pinecone, a leading fully managed hosted vector database

inputParams.label: File Upload
inputParams.name: fileUpload
inputParams.description: Allow file upload on the chat

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
**File Upload**

This allows file upload on the chat. Uploaded files will be upserted on the fly to the vector store.

**Note:**
- You can only turn on file upload for one vector store at a time.
- At least one Document Loader node should be connected to the document input.
- Document Loader should be file types like PDF, DOCX, TXT, etc.

**How it works**
- Uploaded files will have the metadata updated with the chatId.
- This will allow the file to be associated with the chatId.
- When querying, metadata will be filtered by chatId to retrieve files associated with the chatId.

inputParams.label: Pinecone Text Key
inputParams.name: pineconeTextKey
inputParams.description: The key in the metadata for storing text. Default to `text`

inputParams.label: Top K
inputParams.name: topK
inputParams.description: Number of top results to fetch. Default to 4

inputParams.label: Fetch K (for MMR Search)
inputParams.name: fetchK
inputParams.description: Number of initial documents to fetch for MMR reranking. Default to 20. Used only when the search type is MMR

inputParams.label: Lambda (for MMR Search)
inputParams.name: lambda
inputParams.description: Number between 0 and 1 that determines the degree of diversity among the results, where 0 corresponds to maximum diversity and 1 to minimum diversity. Used only when the search type is MMR

inputAnchors.label: Record Manager
inputAnchors.name: recordManager
inputAnchors.description: Keep track of the record to prevent duplication

data.label: OpenAI Embeddings
data.name: openAIEmbeddings
data.description: OpenAI API to generate embeddings for a given text

data.label: ChatOpenAI
data.name: chatOpenAI
data.description: Wrapper around OpenAI large language models that use the Chat endpoint

inputParams.label: Stop Sequence
inputParams.name: stopSequence
inputParams.description: List of stop words to use when generating. Use comma to separate multiple stop words.

inputParams.label: Allow Image Uploads
inputParams.name: allowImageUploads
inputParams.description: Allow image input. Refer to the docs for more details.

inputParams.label: Image Resolution
inputParams.description: This parameter controls the resolution in which the model views the image.
inputParams.name: imageResolution
